intro: Dipcadi kuriensis, commonly known as the Kuriensis squill, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Amaryllidaceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces a flowering stem that bears clusters of white, bell-shaped flowers. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky or gravelly soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
